title: How to become a South African diplomat - Quora

response.answer_text: Satisfying Aspects: variety of work tasksprestige of working in the Foreign Serviceopportunities to travel and live abroadDemanding aspects: having to move to another country every few yearsbeing assigned to countries with health hazards or harsh climatesunstable governmentspoor living conditions sometimesRequirements: A foreign affairs officer should: have tact, discretion and self-control;good interpersonal and communication skillsintelligent, adaptable and dedicatedhave pleasant personality and sociability;prepared to work in any countryspeak fluently and good at learning languagesfit and healthy, with good general knowledgepass a selection processprepared to first work in South Africa before being placed overseashold South African citizenshipobtain security clearance for yourself and spouse, if applicableSchool Subjects: National Senior Certificate meeting degree requirements for a degree course. Each institution will have its own minimum entry requirements. Compulsory Subjects: LanguagesRecommended Subjects: History, Geography, EconomicsTo follow this career path throughout your tertiary studies, you should be involved in the Humanities Faculty (a course within the faculty). Training: The Department of Foreign Affairs offers a 3-year training course at their training centre in Pretoria to selected candidates who are in possession of at least a BA degree or equivalent qualification. Course content includes: protocol, diplomatic, political and economical reportage and how to influence foreign policy.

I would imagine that you would need to join a political party and make your ambitions known to the people in charge. A useful set of skills in a South African context would be languages; domestic, regional and global. A political science qualification and a desire to serve. Ultimately, the art of diplomacy seems to have all but died out in the modern world. Most disputes between nations seem to be settled by sanctions or military action and discussions tend to be overshadowed by the threat of the same.
